78,D,The Ideal Toy Company debuts the Evel Knievel stunt-cycle, which would go on to become one of the best-selling toys of Christmas 1973.
79,None,American Country Countdown, a country music-oriented spin off of the nationally syndicated radio program American Top 40, debuts with host Don Bowman. The countdown, featuring the top 40 country hits of the week according to the Billboard magazine Hot Country Singles chart, becomes a major success.
80,D,Spiro T. Agnew resigns as Vice President of the United States. In federal court in Baltimore, Maryland, he pleads no contest to charges of income tax evasion on $29,500 he received in 1967, while he was governor of Maryland. He is fined $10,000 and put on 3 years' probation.
81,D,The New York Mets win the National League pennant.
82,None,The Saturday Night Massacre: President Richard Nixon orders Attorney General Elliot Richardson to dismiss Watergate Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox. Richardson refuses and resigns, along with Deputy Attorney General William Ruckelshaus. Solicitor General Robert Bork, third in line at the Department of Justice, then fires Cox. The event raises calls for Nixon's impeachment.[8]
83,None,The Oakland A's repeat as champions of Major League Baseball, defeating the New York Mets 5
84,None,The Canon City meteorite, a 1.4 kilogram chondrite type meteorite, strikes Earth in Fremont County, Colorado.
85,D,Watergate scandal: Acting Attorney General Robert Bork appoints Leon Jaworski as the new Watergate Special Prosecutor.[9]
86,None,Pan Am Flight 160, a Boeing 707-321C, crashes at Logan International Airport, Boston, killing three.
87,None,Mariner program: NASA launches Mariner 10 toward Mercury (on March 29, 1974, it becomes the first space probe to reach that planet).
88,U,The Congress of the United States overrides President Richard Nixon's veto of the War Powers Resolution, which limits presidential power to wage war without congressional approval.
89,U,Walt Disney Productions' 21st feature film, Robin Hood, is released to critical praise and box office success, though critical reception has gradually waned over the years.
90,None,Egypt and Israel sign a United States-sponsored cease-fire accord.
91,D,Skylab program: NASA launches Skylab 4 (Gerald Carr, William Pogue, Edward Gibson) from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on an 84-day mission.
92,D,President Richard Nixon signs the Trans-Alaska Pipeline Authorization Act into law, authorizing the construction of the Alaska Pipeline.
93,None,Watergate scandal: In Orlando, Florida, President Richard Nixon tells 400 Associated Press managing editors I'm not a crook."[8]

column6: with Allen winning Best Director. George Lucas' Star Wars wins six awards
column7: while Fred Zinnemann's Julia and Herbert Ross' The Turning Point both receive eleven nominations each.

The Volkswagen Westmoreland Assembly plant near New Stanton
column4: Pennsylvania is dedicated

abstract: The U.S. Senate votes 68
St. Paul
column4: Minnesota becomes the second U.S. city to repeal its gay rights ordinance after Anita Bryant's successful 1977 anti-gay campaign in Dade County
column5: Florida.

abstract: Willow Island disaster
WAC abolished; women integrated into regular Army.
Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds gets his 3
column4: 000th major league hit.

abstract: Mavis Hutchinson
column5: becomes the first woman to run across the U.S.; her trek took 69 days.

abstract: A bomb explodes in the security section of Northwestern University
column4: wounding a security guard (the first Unabomber attack).

abstract: In Atlantic City
column4: New Jersey
column5: Resorts International
column6: the first legal casino in the eastern United States
column7: opens.

abstract: Indianapolis 500: Al Unser wins his third race
column4: and the first for car owner Jim Hall.

abstract: California voters approve Proposition 13
column4: which slashes property taxes nearly 60%.

abstract: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints extends the priesthood and temple blessings to "all worthy males"
column4: ending a general policy of excluding "Canaanites" from priesthood ordination and temple ordinances.

abstract: Affirmed becomes only the 11th horse to ever win the Triple Crown by defeating Alydar in the 110th running of the Belmont Stakes.[11]
Serial killer David Berkowitz
column4: the "Son of Sam
column5:
is sentenced to 365 years in prison.
42,D,The musical film Grease is released, starring 24-year-old New Jersey born actor John Travolta and 29-year-old British-Australian actress and singer Olivia Newton-John.[12]
43,D,Garfield, which eventually becomes the world's most widely syndicated comic strip, makes its debut nationwide.
44,None,The rainbow flag of the LGBT movement flies for the first time (in its original form) at the San Francisco Gay Freedom Day Parade.
45,U,The U.S. scientific satellite Seasat is launched.
46,U,University of California Regents v. Bakke: The Supreme Court of the United States bars quota systems in college admissions but affirms the constitutionality of programs which give advantages to minorities.
47,U,Actor Bob Crane is found bludgeoned to death in his Scottsdale, Arizona, apartment. The crime is never solved.
48,U,President Jimmy Carter declares an unprecedented state emergency and evacuation immediately following the revelation that Niagara Falls, New York neighborhood Love Canal was built on a toxic waste dump.
49,None,During a preseason game against the Oakland Raiders, New England Patriots wide receiver Darryl Stingley sustains a spinal cord injury on a hit from Jack Tatum, leaving Stingley a quadriplegic.[13] He will die from complications of his injury on April 5, 2007.
50,None,The 5.8 .mw-parser-output .tooltip-dotted{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}Mw Santa Barbara earthquake affected the central coast of California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (Very strong), causing 65 injuries and $12 million in financial losses.
51,U,Double Eagle II becomes the first balloon to successfully cross the Atlantic Ocean, flying from Presque Isle, Maine, to Miserey, France.
52,None,Camp David Accords: Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat begin the peace process at Camp David, Maryland.
53,D,WKRP in Cincinnati premieres on CBS.
54,D,PSA Flight 182, a Boeing 727, collides with a small private airplane and crashes in San Diego, California; 144 are killed.
55,D,Giuseppe Verdi's opera Otello makes its first appearance on Live from the Met, in a complete production of the opera starring Jon Vickers. This is the first complete television broadcast of the opera in the U.S. since the historic 1948 one.
56,U,The New York Yankees defeat the Boston Red Sox 5
57,D,Pier 39 opens on Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, as a tourist attraction.
58,U,President Jimmy Carter signs a bill that authorizes the minting of the Susan B. Anthony dollar.
59,None,President Jimmy Carter signs a bill into law which allows homebrewing of beer in the United States.
60,D,The New York Yankees clinch their 22nd World Series championship, defeating the Dodgers 7
61,U,John Carpenter's low-budget slasher film, Halloween, starring Jamie Lee Curtis and Donald Pleasence, is released.
62,D,President Jimmy Carter signs the Humphrey
63,D,California voters defeat the Briggs Initiative that would have prohibited gay school teachers.
64,U,Theodore Roosevelt and Badlands National Park is established.
65,U,The Star Wars Holiday Special airs on CBS; this is its first and only airing.
66,None,Mass murder/suicide of 909 Americans in Jonestown, Guyana under the direction of Jim Jones.
67,None,The first U.S. Take Back the Night march occurs in San Francisco.
68,D,In San Francisco, California, Mayor George Moscone and City Supervisor Harvey Milk are assassinated by former Supervisor Dan White.[14]
69,None,The Southern Crescent passenger train derails at Shipman, Virginia, killing six and injuring 60.[15]
70,U,Dianne Feinstein succeeds the murdered George Moscone as San Francisco, California's first woman mayor (she serves until January 8, 1988).
71,U,Lufthansa heist: Six men rob a Lufthansa cargo facility in New York City's Kennedy airport.
72,D,The first Susan B. Anthony dollar enters circulation.
73,D,Cleveland, Ohio becomes the first major American city to go into default since the Great Depression, under Mayor Dennis Kucinich.
74,D,Superman is released in theaters in the United States.
75,U,Chicago serial killer John Wayne Gacy, who is subsequently convicted of the murder of 33 young men, is arrested.
76,D,United Airlines Flight 173 during a flight leg from Denver, Colorado, to Portland, Oregon, makes a forced emergency landing in a suburban neighborhood in Portland after running out of fuel, killing 10 of 189 people on board.[16]
0,None,The United States and the People's Republic of China establish full diplomatic relations.
1,U,The State of Ohio agrees to pay $675,000 to families of those who were dead or injured from the Kent State shootings.
2,U,The Music for UNICEF Concert is held at the United Nations General Assembly to raise money for UNICEF and promote the Year of the Child. It is broadcast the following day in the United States and around the world. Hosted by The Bee Gees, other performers include Donna Summer, ABBA, Rod Stewart and Earth, Wind & Fire. A soundtrack album is later released.
3,U,Former U.S. Attorney General John N. Mitchell is released on parole after 19 months at a federal prison in Alabama.
4,None,Super Bowl XIII: The Pittsburgh Steelers defeat the Dallas Cowboys 35
5,D,Brenda Ann Spencer opens fire at a school in San Diego, California, killing two faculty members and wounding eight students. Her response to the action, I don’t like Mondays
column6:
inspired the Boomtown Rats to make a song of the same name.
6,None,Averaged over the contiguous United States, this is the coldest month since at least 1880 with a mean temperature of 21.92 °F or −5.60 °C as against an 1895 to 1974 January mean of 29.99 °F or −1.12 °C.[1]
7,None,The maximum temperature at 31.26 °F or −0.41 °C is also the coldest on record for any month and the only occasion when the area-averaged contiguous US mean maximum has fallen below freezing.[2]
8,U,The intense February 13, 1979 Windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a 1/2-mile-long section of the Hood Canal Bridge.
9,D,In Kabul, Muslim extremists kidnap the American ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs, who is later killed during a gunfight between his kidnappers and police.
10,U,This Old House premieres on PBS.
11,D,A total solar eclipse occurred in North America.
12,D,The annual Mardi Gras celebration in New Orleans, Louisiana is canceled due to a strike called by the New Orleans Police Department.
13,D,28
14,None,The U.S. Voyager I space probe photos reveal Jupiter's rings.
15,None,The first fully functional Space Shuttle orbiter, Columbia, is delivered to the John F. Kennedy Space Center, to be prepared for its first launch.
16,D,In a ceremony at the White House, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel sign the Egyptian
17,U,America's most serious nuclear power plant accident at Three Mile Island, Pennsylvania.
18,None,Nickelodeon debuts on cable television, playing children's television shows 24 hours a day. Pinwheel, which first premiered on the channel C-3 in 1977, was one of the first shows to be broadcast on the channel.
19,D,Major League Baseball umpires go on strike, forcing replacements from the minor leagues, college and high school to be used for the first seven weeks of the season. Union umpires return to work May 18.
20,D,The 51st Academy Awards ceremony, hosted by Johnny Carson, is held at Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Michael Cimino's The Deer Hunter wins five awards, including Best Picture and Best Director for Cimino. The film is also tied with Warren Beatty and Buck Henry's Heaven Can Wait in receiving nine nominations each. The ceremony marks the final public appearances of actors Jack Haley and John Wayne; they would both die two months later.
21,U,A tornado hits Wichita Falls, Texas, killing 42.
22,U,President Jimmy Carter is attacked by a swamp rabbit while fishing in his hometown of Plains, Georgia.
23,None,The Albert Einstein Memorial is unveiled at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, DC.
24,D,The unemployment rate drops to 5.6%, the low point for the late 1970s business cycle and the lowest since July 1974.
25,U,A Unabomber bomb injures Northwestern University graduate student John Harris.
26,U,In San Francisco, gay people riot after hearing the verdict for Dan White, assassin of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.
27,U,The Montreal Canadiens defeat the New York Rangers 4 games to 1 in the best-of-seven series, winning the Stanley Cup.
28,U,American Airlines Flight 191: In Chicago, a DC-10 crashes during takeoff at O'Hare International Airport, killing 271 on board and 2 people on the ground. It is the deadliest aviation accident to have occurred in the United States.
29,U,John Spenkelink is executed in Florida, in the first use of the electric chair in America after the reintroduction of death penalty in 1976.
30,U,Six-year-old Etan Patz disappears in New York City. The incident helps spark the missing children's movement.
31,None,Indianapolis 500: Rick Mears wins the race for the first time, and car owner Roger Penske for the second time.
32,U,McDonald's introduces the Happy Meal, there was no toy as seen from the commercial.
33,U,The Seattle SuperSonics win the NBA Championship against the Washington Bullets.
34,D,Jimmy Carter and Leonid Brezhnev sign the SALT II agreement in Vienna.
35,U,A Nicaraguan National Guard soldier kills ABC TV news correspondent Bill Stewart and his interpreter Juan Espinosa. Other members of the news crew capture the killing on tape.
36,D,The Susan B. Anthony dollar is introduced in the U.S.
37,D,President Jimmy Carter signs the first directive for secret aid to the opponents of the pro-Soviet regime in Kabul.
38,None,Los Angeles passes its gay and lesbian civil rights bill.
39,D,NASA's first orbiting space station Skylab begins its return to Earth, after being in orbit for 6 years and 2 months.
40,D,A Disco Demolition Night publicity stunt goes awry at Comiskey Park, forcing the Chicago White Sox to forfeit their game against the Detroit Tigers. Local Rock Radio station WLUP attended the event
41,None,President Carter speaks to Americans about ‘’a crisis of confidence.’’ The speech will come to be known as ‘’the malaise speech,’’ though Carter never used the word ‘’malaise.’’
42,D,Nicaraguan dictator General Anastasio Somoza Debayle resigns and flees to Miami, Florida.
43,U,The Sandinista National Liberation Front concludes a successful revolutionary campaign against the U.S.-backed Somoza dictatorship and assumes power in Nicaragua.
44,U,New York Yankees catcher and team captain Thurman Munson is killed in an airplane crash at age 32 during touch-and-go landings in Canton, Ohio.
45,D,The 5.7 .mw-parser-output .tooltip-dotted{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}Mw Coyote Lake earthquake affected the South Bay and Central Coast areas of California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (Very strong), causing 16 injuries and $500,000 in damage.
46,U,Raymond Washington, co-founder of the Crips, today one of the largest, most notorious gangs in the United States, is shot and killed 5 months after his arrest for quadruple murder (his killers have not yet been identified).
47,U,Michael Jackson releases his first breakthrough album Off the Wall. It sells 7 million copies in the United States alone, making it a 7x platinum album.
48,U,A national referendum is held in which Somali voters approve a new liberal constitution, promulgated by President Siad Barre to placate the United States.
49,None,The U.S. Pioneer 11 becomes the first spacecraft to visit Saturn, when it passes the planet at a distance of 21,000 km.
50,U,Hurricane Frederic makes landfall at 10:00 p.m. on Alabama's Gulf Coast.
51,None,The Sugarhill Gang release Rapper's Delight, the first rap single to become a Top 40 hit on the Billboard Hot 100.
52,None,The largest anti-nuclear demonstration to date is held in New York City, where almost 200,000 people attend.[4]
53,D,6
54,None,A major gay rights march in the United States takes place in Washington, D.C., involving many tens of thousands of people.
55,D,The 6.4 Mw Imperial Valley earthquake affected Southern California and northern Baja California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), causing 91 injuries and $30 million in damage.
56,U,President Jimmy Carter signs a law establishing the Department of Education.
57,U,1979 World Series: The Pittsburgh Pirates defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 4 games to 3, to win their 5th World Series Title.
58,U,Iran hostage crisis: Iranian Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urges his people to demonstrate on November 4 and to expand attacks on United States and Israeli interests.
59,U,Assata Shakur (ne' Joanne Chesimard), a former member of Black Panther Party and Black Liberation Army, is liberated from a Clinton, New Jersey prison and soon shuttled off to Cuba where she remains under political asylum.
60,None,Greensboro massacre in Greensboro, North Carolina, five members of the Communist Workers Party are shot to death and seven are wounded by a group of Klansmen and neo-Nazis, during a Death to the Klan" rally.

column4: Rock Island and Pacific Railroad operates its final train.

abstract: November 12
A Texaco oil rig breaks through to a mine under Lake Peigneur.
Millions of viewers tune into the U.S. soap opera Dallas to learn who shot lead character J. R. Ewing. The "Who shot J. R.?" event is a national obsession.
MGM Grand fire: A fire at the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino on the Las Vegas Strip kills 85 people.
John Lennon is shot and killed by Mark David Chapman in front of The Dakota apartment building in New York City.[6]
Berkeley Breathed's comic strip Bloom County debuts in newspapers.
CERCLA is enacted by the U.S. Congress.
Four people are murdered and four others are injured by two armed robbers at Bob's Big Boy on La Cienega Boulevard in Los Angeles.

column5:

0,U,Women in Housing and Finance: conduct first meeting in New York City.
1,U,United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.
2,D,Ronald Reagan is sworn in as the 40th president of the United States, and George H. W. Bush is sworn in as the 43rd vice president. Minutes later, Iran releases the 52 Americans held for 444 days, ending the Iran hostage crisis.
3,None,Super Bowl XV: The Oakland Raiders defeat the Philadelphia Eagles 27
4,D,A fire at the Las Vegas Hilton hotel-casino kills eight and injures 198.
5,U,President Reagan delivers his first address to the 97th Congress.
6,U,After 19 years hosting the CBS Evening News, Walter Cronkite signs off for the last time.
7,U,Three workers are killed and five are injured during a test of the Space Shuttle Columbia.
8,None,Michael Donald is lynched in Mobile, Alabama.
9,U,President Ronald Reagan is shot in the chest outside a Washington, D.C., hotel by John Hinckley Jr. Two police officers and Press Secretary James Brady are also wounded.
10,U,The 53rd Academy Awards, hosted by Johnny Carson, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Robert Redford's directorial debut, Ordinary People, wins four awards, including Best Picture and Best Director. David Lynch's The Elephant Man and Martin Scorsese's Raging Bull tie in receiving eight nominations each.
11,None,The Space Shuttle program: Space Shuttle Columbia (John Young, Robert Crippen) launches on the STS-1 mission, returning to Earth on April 14.
12,None,A Minor League Baseball game between the Rochester Red Wings and the Pawtucket Red Sox at McCoy Stadium in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, becomes the longest professional baseball game in history: 8 hours and 25 minutes/33 innings (the 33rd inning is not played until June 23).
13,None,The 5.9 .mw-parser-output .tooltip-dotted{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}Mw Westmorland earthquake shook the Imperial Valley of California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (Very strong), causing $1
14,D,The Jamaican reggae singer Bob Marley dies at age 36 from cancer.
15,U,Donna Payant is murdered by serial killer Lemuel Smith, the first time a female correctional officer has been killed on-duty in the United States.
16,D,The United States enters the severe early 1980s recession, exactly a year after the more minor 1980 recession ended; the unemployment rate is 7.2%
17,U,The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that five homosexual men in Los Angeles, California, have a rare form of pneumonia seen only in patients with weakened immune systems (the first recognized cases of AIDS).
18,U,Major League Baseball goes on strike, forcing the cancellation of 38 percent of the schedule.
19,U,Raiders of the Lost Ark, directed by Steven Spielberg  is released as the first film of the Indiana Jones film series.
20,None,Wayne Williams, a 23-year-old African American, is arrested and charged with the murders of two other African Americans. He is later accused of 28 others, in the Atlanta child murders.
21,D,Morris Edwin Robert, armed with a machine gun, holds hostages in the FBI section at the Atlanta, Georgia Federal Building. After three hours, the hostages are rescued and Robert is killed in a shootout with federal agents.
22,D,President Reagan nominates the first woman, Sandra Day O'Connor, to the Supreme Court of the United States.
23,U,California Governor Jerry Brown, faced with a Mediterranean fruit fly infestation, chooses to delay the aerial spraying of malathion, in favor of continuing ground-based eradication efforts.
24,U,First release of Donkey Kong and debut of Mario.
25,U,Walt Disney Productions' 24th feature film, The Fox and the Hound, is released after a six-month delay due to the departure of Don Bluth and his animation team from the studio. The film receives mixed-to-positive reviews and is a box office success.
26,U,Hyatt Regency walkway collapse: Two skywalks filled with people at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City, Missouri collapse into a crowded atrium lobby, killing 114.
27,U,Israeli aircraft bomb Beirut, destroying multi-story apartment blocks containing the offices of PLO associated groups, killing approximately 300 civilians and resulting in worldwide condemnation and a U.S. embargo on the export of aircraft to Israel.[1]
28,U,Adam Walsh, 6, is kidnapped from a Sears store in Hollywood, Florida.
29,None,MTV (Music Television) is launched on cable television in the United States.
30,U,President Ronald Reagan fires 11,359 striking air-traffic controllers who ignored his order for them to return to work.
31,D,The Washington Star ceases publication after 128 years.
32,None,Major League Baseball resumes from the strike with the All-Star Game in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.
33,D,Exactly two weeks after his disappearance, the severed head of 6-year-old Hollywood, Florida native Adam Walsh is found in a canal in Vero Beach, Florida; to this day the rest of the boy's body has never been recovered.
34,U,The original Model 5150 IBM PC (with a 4.77 MHz Intel 8088 processor) is released in the United States at a base price of $1,565.
35,U,Gulf of Sidra incident (1981): Libyan leader Muammar al-Gaddafi sends 2 Sukhoi Su-22 fighter jets to intercept 2 U.S. fighters over the Gulf of Sidra. The American jets destroy the Libyan fighters.
36,U,President Ronald Reagan appoints the first female U.S. Supreme Court Justice, Sandra Day O'Connor.
37,D,Mark David Chapman is sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, after being convicted of murdering John Lennon in Manhattan eight months earlier.
38,D,A bomb explodes at the U.S. Air Force base in Ramstein, West Germany, injuring 20 people.
39,U,Picasso's painting Guernica" is moved from New York City to Madrid.

26,None,Approximately 800,000 people gather for a walk to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California.
27,None,Five days before his 48th birthday, Al Unser became the oldest winner of the Indianapolis 500 and only the second driver to win the event four times.
28,U,During a visit to Berlin, Germany, U.S. President Ronald Reagan challenges Soviet General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall.

37,None,Northwest Airlines Flight 255 (a McDonnell Douglas MD-82) crashes on takeoff from Detroit Metropolitan Airport in Romulus, Michigan just West of Detroit killing all but one (4-year old Cecelia Cichan) of the 156 people on board (among them Nick Vanos, a center for the Phoenix Suns).
38,U,ABC News chief Middle East correspondent Charles Glass escapes his Hezbollah kidnappers in Beirut, Lebanon, after 62 days in captivity.

53,U,Iran

56,None,Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington found the Valve Corporation.

63,None,Shortly after attending the Mike Tyson

68,U,Ricardo López is found dead in his apartment by Hollywood Police after reports of a foul odor in the room. After watching his suicide tape, police contact Scotland Yard to warn them about an explosive package on its way to Björk's home in London. London Metro Police Officers intercept the package and safely detonate it, leaving Björk unharmed.

75,U,The Fox News Channel is launched on U.S. cable systems.

77,U,November 5 — At least sixty-six people become sick and one baby dies as a result of drinking apple juice infected with E. coli.

81,None,The New York Yankees defeat the Atlanta Braves to win their first World Series in 18 years.

column6: J. D. B.
column7: in a dispute of his confession made during a North Carolina theft investigation.[151] Writing for the majority
column8: Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor said that "This case presents the question whether the age of a child subjected to police questioning is relevant to the custody analysis of Miranda v. Arizona
column9: 384 U. S. 436 (1966). It is beyond dispute that children will often feel bound to submit to police questioning when an adult in the same circumstances would feel free to leave. Seeing no reason for police officers or courts to blind themselves to that commonsense reality
column10: we hold that a child's age properly informs the Miranda custody analysis."

column7: it is invalid unless California can demonstrate that it passes strict scrutiny—that is

column4: in fact
column5: not a "sale with restrictions on use"

column9: you own it" principle asserted by such organizations who would like to resell items.[290]

column4: state-hired prison company in federal court. The ruling went against prisoner Richard Lee Pollard in a dispute of damages over a violation of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment
column5: claiming that Wackenhut/GEO

column8: Associate Justice Stephen Breyer said that "... the existence of an Eighth Amendment-based damages action ... against ... a privately operated federal prison .. state tort law authorizes adequate alternative damages actions
column9: ... actions that provide both significant deterrence and compensation ... For these reasons
column12: a federal prisoner seeks damages from privately employed personnel working at a privately operated federal prison
column13: where the conduct allegedly amounts to a violation of the Eighth Amendment
column14: and where that conduct is of a kind that typically falls within the scope of traditional state tort law (such as the conduct involving improper medical care at issue here)
column15: the prisoner must seek a remedy under state tort law. We cannot imply a Bivens remedy in such a case. The judgment of the Ninth Circuit is reversed."

column10: violated the TCPA by repeatedly using an automatic telephone dialing system or prerecorded or artificial voice to call Mims's cellular phone without his consent.[20] Writing for the unanimous court
column11: Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said that "We find no convincing reason to read into the TCPA's permissive grant of jurisdiction to state courts any barrier to the U. S. district courts' exercise of the general federal-question jurisdiction ... We hold

abstract: The Supreme Court holds in a 6–3 decision that the first-sale doctrine applies to the domestic sale of foreign copies of copyrighted work lawfully made abroad. The first-sale doctrine (also known as the "exhaustion rule") is a core feature of both copyright and patent law. The doctrine holds that intellectual property rights associated with a particular copy of a work are exhausted once there is an authorized sale or manufacture of that copy. Although the decision does not mention patent law
column4: the case also has obvious implications for patents. The case may also have some implications for streaming of copyrighted content based on national origin. A Thailand man
column5: Supap Kirtsaeng
column6: had moved to the US and set up a side business of importing textbooks from Thailand and reselling them on eBay in the US for a substantial profit. The imported books were not counterfeit but actual publisher-printed versions of textbooks. The publisher

abstract: The United States imposes visa restrictions on over 250 members of the Nicaraguan government along with sanctions on three entities for "repressive action" and failure to control migrant smuggling through Nicaragua.[260]
Houston Astros pitcher Ronel Blanco is ejected from the game against the Oakland Athletics and receives a 10-game suspension after foreign substances were found in his glove.[261]
U.S. President Joe Biden and presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump agree to hold a presidential debate on June 27
column4: hosted by CNN
column5: which will be the earliest general election debate in modern history in the United States. A second debate will be held in September.[262]

abstract: The United States Supreme Court lets Louisiana use a new congressional map with two majority-Black congressional districts in the 2024 United States House of Representatives elections.[263]
The Dow Jones index surpasses 40
column4: 000 points for the first time.[264]

abstract: The European Union opens a formal investigation into Meta for potential breaches in online content rules relating to child safety on Facebook and Instagram
column4: violating the Digital Services Act.[265]

abstract: United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken announces a $2 billion additional military aid package for Ukraine
column4: aimed at investing in Ukraine's industrial base.[266]

abstract: The House of Representatives passes a bill which would defund certain offices if President Biden impedes any weapons shipments to Israel. The President is expected to veto the bill if it passes the Senate.[267]
Severe storms kill four people in Houston and shut off power for nearly one million buildings in Texas and Louisiana.[268][269]

abstract: The 2024 United States presidential election will take place.[273]
